column3: I like the idea, I'm not a fan of using abandonware, it could include security issues which shouldn't happen to release builds.

Concept ACK. Agree that we want to be using a maintained version.

Have any distro's switched to this fork?

As @fanquake said, we'll obviously need to double-check that it doesn't break our current usage. We should also do a quick audit that it doesn't steal keys, since it uses the net for a timestamp.

> Have any distro's switched to this fork?

Ubuntu Disco (19.04)  - https://packages.ubuntu.com/disco/osslsigncode
Debian Buster (10.0) - https://packages.debian.org/buster/osslsigncode

<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->

The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers.

<!--174a7506f384e20aa4161008e828411d-->
### Conflicts
No conflicts as of last run.
> Concept ACK. This PR actually came in really handy when signing the recent releases, as I ran into the compatibility issues.\n\nLooks like this can go out of draft status then?
> Looks like this can go out of draft status then?\n\nRebased and removed `[WIP]`.
Concept ACK feb507577797518d0bee1774327d215e19d1ba34 given that this upstream is now used in Ubuntu and Debian
I actually think we should prefer being specific here, so that we know at a glance what version we're using.\nI assume there's a ```libssl1.1-dev``` as well?
TODO: report to upstream that their release tarball isn't bootstrapped.

I agree that more specific would be preferred, however from what I can see, it doesn't look like it. 
In a `ubuntu:bionic` container:
```bash
apt search libssl
libssl-dev/bionic-updates,bionic-security,now 1.1.1-1ubuntu2.1~18.04.4 amd64 [installed]
libssl1.0-dev/bionic-updates,bionic-security 1.0.2n-1ubuntu5.3 amd64
libssl1.0.0/bionic-updates,bionic-security,now 1.0.2n-1ubuntu5.3 amd64
this makes sense, debian tends to only have versioned `-dev` packages when supporting an old version
